sen.j: 古来中国では、正月の1日をニワトリの日、2日を狗（犬）の日、3日をイノシシ（ブタ）の日、4日をヒツジの日、5日をウシの日、6日をウマの日としていた。
sen.e: In ancient China, each day in the new year's week was designated as the day of a certain animal, with the first day as the day of the rooster, the second day as the day of the dog, the third the boar, the fourth the sheep, the fifth the ox, the sixth the horse respectively.

sen.e: There was a custom to eat hot soup with seven kinds of vegetables, which was introduced to Japan and it eventually became the seven -herb rice porridge.

sen.j: 日本では平安時代から始められ、江戸時代より一般に定着した。
sen.e: Japanese people started eating the dish in the Heian period, and by the Edo period, it had taken root among commoners.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の公式行事となり、征夷大将軍以下全ての武士が七種粥を食べて人日の節句を祝った。
sen.e: It subsequently became the official event of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to have the dish on January 7, when all the warriors including the great general celebrated the day eating nanakusa rice porridge.

sen.j: また、この日は新年になって初めて爪を切る日ともされる。
sen.e: Jinjitsu is also supposed to be the first day in the new year for people to clip their nails.

sen.j: 七種を浸した水に爪をつけて、柔かくしてから切ると、その年は風邪をひかないと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that before clipping, bathing one's hands in the water with seven herbs to soften the nails makes one not catch cold throughout the year.
